docs.lead_paragraph: A guest commentary by Kathryn Roberts, Ph.D., president and chief executive of Ecumen, one of the country's largest nonprofit senior housing and services companies, based in Minneapolis. She also is a member of the board of directors of the American Association of Homes and Services for the Aging, an association of nonprofit service providers. -- Jane Gross

headline.main: The Candidates' Silence on Long-Term Care

docs.abstract: Could transforming how we pay for aging be the baby boomers' next big act?

docs.lead_paragraph: MBIA agreed on Wednesday to take control of nearly $200 billion of municipal bonds currently backed by a rival bond insurer, FGIC, in a move that could help its competitor avoid bankruptcy.

headline.main: MBIA to Aid Troubled Bond Insurer

docs.abstract: MBIA agreed on Wednesday to take control of nearly $200 billion of municipal bonds currently backed by a rival bond insurer, FGIC, in a move that could help its competitor avoid bankruptcy. The agreement between the two companies calls for the municipal bond issuers to pay their premiums in advance, transferring $741 million to MBIA. [...]

docs.lead_paragraph: It has been a rough week for Nelson Castro, the candidate for an Assembly seat in the Bronx. Mr. Castro has had to contend with disclosures that he was charged with grand larceny four years ago for collecting $5,000 in unemployment checks while holding a job. He pleaded guilty to a charge of petit larceny, a misdemeanor, and was sentenced to three years' probation and ordered to pay back the money.

headline.main: Bronx Candidate Tries to Move Beyond Conviction

docs.abstract: Nelson Castro, a candidate for an Assembly seat in the Bronx, has a misdemeanor larceny conviction in his past.
